"THE PRATH OP 1- "The Prime Minister informed the Cabinet that Mr ArthurMr ARTHURGRIFFITH. Griffith, who had been one of the signatories of the IrishTreaty on behalf of the Provisional Government of Ireland,had died suddenly of heart failure.The Prime Minister said that the King was waiting tobe informed whether it was expedient that he should send a message of regret to the Provisional Government.The Cabinet were reminded of the firm and loyalattitude towards the Treaty displayed throughout by Mr.Griffith. Mr Griffith would probably have been a Ministerof the Grown if the Constitution had been passed, and hehad, at the moment of his death, been connected with aGovernment which was fighting a loyal battle, so far as theCrown was concerned. At the time of his death, however, hehad been merely President of the Dail.The Cabinet agreed -(a) That the Prime Minister should advise theKing to send a message to Mr Arthur Griffith'swidow, on personal lines:(b) That the Prime Minister and the signatories of the Treaty should send a message of regretto Mr Michael Collins . WlAK REPA- 8. With reference to Cabinet 44 (22), the Cabinet had' * before them a copy of the proposals presented to the Alliesby the Prime Minister at his meeting with M. Poincare'' andM. Theunis, on the previous day (Paper C.P.-4157).The Prime Minister began by giving his colleagues an appreciation of the present position. He had spent sevenhours with M. Poincare and M. Theunls on the previous day,M, Polneare' was n& longer pressing his original proposalsfor a Customs barrier on the line of the Rhine; nor theeven more objectionable proposal for a Customs Service onthe exits of the Ruhr; nor for 60 per cent, of the shares in certain factories on the left bank of the Rhine, includingthe poison gas factories. He was, however, still pressing for the seizure of forests and mines. The more he (the PrimeMinister) and his colleagues in these negotiations examined'these proposals, the more they disliked them. The forestswere the property of the States, and to ask Germany to handover these was as though, if the circumstances were reversed,Germany were to ask the British Government to hand over theforests of Ontario or Quebec. M. Poincare' also wished, to seize the fiscal mines of the Ruhr, which belonged to the reich. His latest proposal had been to form a Company towork these mines, with an Allied Board of three Directorsand a French President. One obvious objection to this wasthat the workmen would not work under such conditions.Eventually he had made'a proposal that the same princeple as had been set forth in the British proposals as regardsthe Customs should be applied in the case of the mines andforests also; that is to say, the revenues from the mines and forests would be paid into a special fund at the reichsbank, which would normally be used, by the GermanGovernment but which could be taken over by the Reparation .Commission in the event of defaxilt by the German Government. One diffx culty in such an arrangement, would "be that the forest "revenue is a State revenue. This had been, pointedout, and it was then suggested t?o&t where the States werenot prepared to pay their quota the Central Governmentshould pay an equivalent amount into the account. Thelatest French idea with regard to supervision of the mineswas something less strict than control, but still involving an objectionable degree of interference. At the end of thediscussion, when M. Poincare declared himself unable toaccept the British, proposals regarding forests and mines,and when he (the Prime Minister) had reiterated the deei-sions of the British Cabinet, it was decided to refer theproposals to a Committee of Experts. The Committee was meeting at that moment, and the latest news indicated noapproach to an agreement, In effect, M. poinear6* s policy was. tantamount to an attempt to break tho Treaty by thesubstitution of French proposals before the ReparationCommission had declared Germany in default.THE LORD PRUT SEAL said he would like the Cabinet togive some latitude to the negotiators, He was not convincedthat an offer of abatement of debt could be made at thepresent moment which would not weaken'the position theCabinet had taken up vis-a-vis America; nor, on the otherhand, could an offer be made of an amount sufficientlysubstantial to evoke the gratitude of the Allies. Any offer which we could make now would neither strike the publicimagination nor' please the Allies , He would suggest thatthe negotiators ought to be empowered to go so far as to saythat during the period of any moratorium granted to Germanyno attempt should be made to collect any back interest dueor -any interest falling to be paid during the currency ofthe moratorium. TEE PRIME MINISTER said that any offer made had to he-regarded not only in its bearing on Prance but also in itsbearing on the negotiations with the United States of America.It might be the case that we should not obtain a penny from France or Italy, but if we made it clear to the United Statesthat the action of America was responsible for the continu-once of chaos in Europe, it would be a negotiating pawnwhen our representative went to Washington. That, he believ-ed, was the view which the Cabinet had taken.THE LORD PRIVY SEAL, in reply to a question, said thatwhen he said "should not collect the interest" he had meant that it should be written off.THE SECRETARY OP STATE FOR WAR said that the difficulty was to find a plan which would carry out the Balfour Motein its bearing on the United States and yet afford a suitableopening for a bargain with the Allies.THE PRIME MINISTER said he assumed that it was the wishof the Cabinet that the British negotiators should stand firm in refusing to hand over the management of the Germanmines and forests.In reply to the Secretary of State for India, THE PRIMEMINISTER, continuing, said he had no objection to a modifiedform of supervision so long as it did not involve actualdirection.THE LORD PRIVY SEAL emphasized the importance of anexact definition being.assigned to the term "supervision".There was no objection to our exercising the right ofinvestigating and verifying facts, in the same way as theGermane had agreed should be done in regard to their Budget.THE PRIME MINISTER agreed, but added that he doubted whether that alone would satisfy the French, who were pre-pared to contemplate with equanimity a rupture betweenPrussia and Bavax"ia.-/Is.;;.- - At this point THE PRIME MINISTER referred to a letterreceived by the Secretary from Major Gaccia, of the IndianForestry Service, which showed clearly that what the french had in mind was the control and exploitation of Germanforests.After further discussion, the Gabinet agreed -(a) That the British negotiators should adhere to the position already taken in regard to german mines and forests i(b) That the British negotiators should be free to deal as they thought best with the quas-tion of bach interest and interest accruingup to the end of the period of any moratoriumwhich, might be granted to the Gezmans .At a later stage the Chancellor of the Exchequer enteredand informed the Gabinet of the position which, had beenreached Tip to that time at the Committee of Experts.THE CHANCELLOR OF THE EXCHEQUER stated that the Frenchwished to establish immediately the control of German mines and forests, and wished to.empower the Reparation Commissionto expropriate the mines and forests if and when they shoulddeem such.action necessary. He had pointed out that if theFrench proceeded by such policy to destroy all confidence in Germany, no reparations would be obtained. The Italians,who were disappointed over their failure to obtain deliveries of coal, had sided with, the French on the question of estab-lishing control of mines and forests, and the Belgians had gone further and had approved also of expropriation. TheJapanese had shared the British view. He (the Chancellorof the Exchequer) had pointed out that he saw no chance ofthe British representative remaining on the ReparationCommission if the policy now proposed were persisted in.There was clearly ho chance of a meeting of Principals that day. It would be better to allow the Experts to concludetheir work, and that the Principals should meet on Monday. The Cabinet took note of the statement ofthe Chancellor of the Exchequer, and agreedthat the Report of the Experts should beawaited before calling a farther meetingof the principal negotiators. Training Centres for Emigrants.
The Committee have discussed the question of emigration and have been informed that various emigration schemes are now being negotiated by the Oversea Settlement Office with Dominion Governments. Until these negotiations are complete further action by the British Government would be superfluous. It has, however, been suggested that Training Centres should be established both in this country and in the Dominions for the purpose of giving elementary instruction in agricultural work to emigrants. The Committee understand that the best training is that given in the Dominions, and a recommendation has been made by the Oversea Settlement Committee that Dominion Governments should be urged to establish farm training centres overseas.
The Committee recommend:-
That the Cabinet should authorise the Oversea Settlement Committee to urge Dominion Governments to establish farm training centres overseas, but should take no steps at present to establish training centres in Great Britain.
